titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Asset Building and Community Development Program (ASSETS), Vice President for Assets, Office Files of Dr. Melvin L. Oliver
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Asset Building and Community Development Program (ASSETS), Vice President for Assets, Office Files of Dr. Melvin L Oliver FA508
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Brian Bleich, The Winthrop Group

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-11-20 00:06:09 -0500.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Asset Building and Community Development Program (ASSETS), Vice President for Assets, Office Files of Dr. Melvin L Oliver
did.abstract: The Asset Building and Community Development Program was established in October 1996 as part of a Foundation-wide program reorganization. The new program supported the work of a range of groups and individuals seeking to build the assets and capacities of poor communities through community-based activities, research, policy analysis, and advocacy. In 2009, the Asset Building and Community Development Program became the Economic Opportunity and Assets Program. Dr. Melvin L. Oliver joined the Ford Foundation in 1996. He served as the Foundation's first Vice President for Asset Building and Community Development and worked on issues relating to poverty, community economic development, and reproductive health. The Office Files of Melvin L. Oliver document his professional activities as Vice President of the Assets Program between 1996 and 2009. The bulk of the collection consists of correspondence concerning such subjects as ongoing grant activity, potential grantees, and Foundation policy, and briefing books from meetings, conferences, and field visits. A couple of files pertaining to Dr. Oliver's pre-Ford research and writing in Sociology during the 1980s can also be found in the collection.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Dr. Melvin L. Oliver was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania in 1950. He received an undergraduate degree from William Penn College in Iowa (1972) and was awarded an M.A. (1974) and a PhD (1977) in Sociology from Washington University in St. Louis. In 1978, he joined the faculty of the University of California Los Angeles, where he worked for the next 17 years. He became known for his work in Sociology, receiving such honors as a fellowship grant from the Ford Foundation in 1982 and the title of "California Professor of the Year" from the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching in 1994.

Dr. Oliver joined the Ford Foundation in 1996. He served as the Foundation's first Vice President for Asset Building and Community Development and worked on issues relating to poverty, community economic development, and reproductive health. In 2004, he returned to academia, accepting an appointment as SAGE Sara Miller McCune Dean of Social Sciences and Professor of Sociology at the University of California Santa Barbara.

bioghist.head: Organizational History
bioghist.p: The Asset Building and Community Development Program was established in October 1996 as part of the Foundation-wide program reorganization in the 1997 fiscal year. It took over existing Foundation programs in Urban Poverty, Rural Poverty and Resources, Reproductive Health and Population, and Program-Related Investments. The Assets Program had three program units: Economic Development; Community and Resource Development; and Human Development and Reproductive Health. In 2009, the Asset Building and Community Development Program became the Economic Opportunity and Assets Program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Office Files of Dr. Melvin L. Oliver, a well-known sociologist, document his professional activities between 1982 and 2009. The bulk of files pertain to his tenure as Vice President of the Assets Program at the Ford Foundation.

processinfo.head: Processing Information Note
processinfo.p: The original total volume of 16 cubic feet accessioned by the Foundation Archives in 2010 has been reduced during processing to 4 cubic feet.

Duplicates, reference files containing papers, magazines, or other items of interest to Dr. Oliver but unrelated to the Foundation or Foundation-related activities, personal records and records from UCLA pre-dating Dr. Oliver's employment at the Foundation were removed from the collection. Some of the accessioned boxes were brought to the Foundation by Dr. Oliver from his office in UCLA and held personal papers or university-specific documentation. These boxes were de-accessioned during processing for return to Dr. Oliver.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: A photograph of Dr. Oliver and a fellow Ford Foundation staff member at the Great Wall of China has been transferred to the Trustees and Staff Photo Collection.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Appendix A: Reports â€“ Unpublished reports written by Ford Foundation staff and consultants were removed from their original folders, scanned and transferred to the Archives' collection of staff and consultant reports. See Appendix A for a list of these reports and their specific assigned number. The reports are listed in alphabetical order by author. The assigned number may be used to access reports in the online catalog.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Completion of a use agreement is required prior to providing scholarly access. See RAC Head of Reference (or applicable designee) for details. Ford Foundation holds title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them. The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection for scholarly purposes. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records more than 10 years old are open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

did.unittitle: Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of Mr. Oliver's incoming and outgoing correspondence and memoranda that Dr. Oliver arranged chronologically by year, and within years, alphabetically by correspondent. Dr. Oliver's separation of external correspondence from internal Ford Foundation memoranda was maintained. Subjects of correspondence include ongoing grant actions, potential grantees, Foundation policy, and other subjects. The files also contain copies of newspaper and magazine articles retained by Dr. Oliver for discussion or reference.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Some of the records in this file are restricted because they are less than 10 years old. The restricted items have been segregated and are inaccessible. The file is open to research, and physical removal of the segregated material is not necessary.
Date Restricted Material -- Contains records less than 10 years old -- Pertinent records are Open to scholarly research in 2018, and 2020.

did.unittitle: Meetings, Conferences and Visits

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: As Vice President, Dr. Oliver traveled extensively, visiting grantee locations, attending conferences, and meeting with other Foundation staff members. This series is comprised of the briefing books and other materials he retained from his travels.

Research and Writing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of two folders. Both pre-date Dr. Oliver's tenure at the Foundation. One contains information retained by Dr. Oliver about his Ford Foundation-funded postdoctoral fellowship administered by the National Science Foundation. The other is an undated paper from the early 1980s containing Dr. Oliver's views on affirmative action.

did.unittitle: "Is Affirmative Action Necessary? One Sociologist's Viewpoint" by Melvin L. Oliver
National Science Foundation Postdoctoral Fellowship
